description.text: A simplified version of the Mendel y-chassis suitable for making with a saw and a drill press.

Cut a rectangle of board 200x136mm. Print the template 1:1, cut it out and fix it to the board with masking tape. Prick though all the hole centres. Remove the paper and centre punch them. 
Drill the large holes 6mm and then use a saw to join them up to make the 6 slots. 
Drill the small holes 3.3mm to take M3 bolts. Drill the medium sized holes 4.2mm-4.5mm for M4 bolts.
Note that the inner holes for the bearing brackets are missing. This is because the position varies according to how the bearings are adjusted. After the bearings have been adjusted fit them and mark through the holes to get the remaining 8 4.2mm holes.
A good material to use is Dibond, a 3mm thick sandwich of PE laminated with aluminium. It is strong but light and easy to machine and not very expensive. You can use it for all the Mendel thick sheet parts.

Anleitung / Instructions:

Benötigte Teile:

  • 9x Gitarrenmechaniken (nur rechts)
  • 3x Gitarrensaiten (z.B. Rotosound NP011)
  • 20mm Buchenrundstab, 1m Länge
  • 5mm CFK Stab, Länge 1m (als Versteifung)
  • 3x passende Scharniere
  • 9x Metall-Schrauben M4x30
  • 9x Flügelmutter M4
  • 18x Beilagscheiben M4 (um den Draht einzufädeln und mit der Flügelmutter zu befestigen)
  • 9x Metall- Schrauben M4x10 (zum Befestigen der Scharniere am Seifenschneider)
  • 9x M4x30 Holzschrauben
  • 1x Querverleimtes Holzbrett 3cm Dicke (z.B. altes Schneidebrett)
  • Epoxyd Harz langsam härtend
  1. Alle Teile Drucken, CFK Stangen und Buchenrundstab auf ca. 230mm ablängen (am realen Objekt nachmessen/Testen).
  2. Rahmenteile mit CFK Stangen und Buchenrundstab auf Probe zusammenstecken, wenn etwas nicht passt nacharbeiten.
  3. Die Rahmenteile, CFK Stäbe und Buchenrundstab mit langsam aushärtendem Epoxid Harz verkleben (z.B. Uhu Endfest 300). Aufpassen das die Löcher für die Gitarrenmechaniken frei bleiben.
  4. Gitarrenmechaniken montieren (Schrauben mit Gefühl anziehen)
  5. M4x30 Schrauben montieren, 2 Beilagscheiben auf der Unterseite montieren und Flügelmutter darauf.
  6. Mit den M4x10 Schrauben die Scharniere montieren. Vor dem Einschrauben zusätzlich Epoxyd Harz in die Bohrlöcher im Rahmen geben, damit die Scharniere 100% halten.
  7. Mit den Holzschrauben auf dem Holzbrett verschrauben.
  8. Gitarrensaiten (Metall) einfädeln, Saiten alle gleichmäßig ausrichten. und mit Gefühl spannen (nicht zu stark Spannen, die Spannung muss nicht sehr hoch sein).
    Benötigte Teile:
  • 9x Gitarrenmechaniken (nur rechts)
  • 20mm Buchenrundstab
  • 5mm CFK Stab (als Versteifung)
  • 3x passende Scharniere
  • 9x Schrauben M4x30
  • 9x Flügelmutter M4
  • 18x Beilagscheiben M4 (um den Draht einzufädeln und mit der Flügelmutter zu befestigen
  • 9x M4x10 zum Befestigen der Scharniere am Seifenschneider
  • 9x M4x30 Holzschrauben
  • 1x Querverleimtes Holzbrett 3cm Dicke (z.B. altes Schneidebrett)
  1. Alle Teile Drucken, CFK Stangen und Buchenrundstab auf ca. 230mm ablängen (am realen Objekt nachmessen/Testen).
  2. Rahmenteile mit CFK Stangen und Buchenrundtsab auf Probe zusammenstecken, wenn etwas nicht passt nacharbeiten.
  3. Die Rahmenteile, CFK Stäbe und Buchenrundstab mit langsam aushärtendem Epoxid Harz verkleben (z.B. Uhu Endfest 300). Aufpassen das die Löcher für die Gitarrenmechaniken frei bleiben.
  4. Gitarrenmechaniken montieren (Schrauben mit Gefühl anziehen)
  5. M4x30 Schrauben montieren, 2 Beilagscheiben auf der Unterseite montieren und Flügelmutter darauf.
  6. Mit den M4x10 Schrauben die Scharniere montieren. Vor dem Einschrauben zusätzlich Epoxyd Harz in die Bohrlöcher im Rahmen geben, damit die Scharniere 100% halten.
  7. Mit den Holzschrauben auf dem Holzbrett verschrauben.
  8. Gitarrensaiten (Metall) einfädeln, Saiten alle gleichmäßig ausrichten. und mit Gefühl spannen (nicht zu stark Spannen, die Spannung muss nicht sehr hoch sein).
  9. Seifenanschlag Links und Rechts ausrichten und mit dem Holzbrett verkleben oder verschrauben. Achtung: Vor dem Verkleben mit einem Seifenstück aus der genutzen Form testen und nicht zu weit am vorderen Rahmen platzieren (da es sonst zu Problemen bei hohen Seifen kommen kann).

Viel Spaß!

Needed Parts:

  • 9x Guitar-mechanics (only right-sided)
  • 3x Guitar strings (e.g.Rotosound NP011)
  • 20mm wooden rod (beech wood)
  • 5mm CFK rod, lenght 1m (for stiffness)
  • 3x hinges (look for fitting ones)
  • 9x Metal-Screw M4x30
  • 9x WingNut M4
  • 18x Washer M4 (fix the cutting wire between the washers and the wingnut)
  • 9x Metal-Screw M4x10 (to attach the hinges to the cutter)
  • 9x M4x30 Wood-Screws
  • 1x an approximately 3cm thick wooden board (e.g. old cutting board)
  1. Print all parts and cut cfk- and wood rods to approximately 230mm length (measure on the real object before cutting)
  2. Put the frame together with the cfk- and wood rods for test and adjust if necessary.
  3. Glue all the frame parts together with the cfk- and wood rods. Use slow epoxy glue for that (not the 5min one). Make sure the holes for the guitar mechanics remain free.
  4. Install the guitar mechanics (be careful when screwing in the screws, do not use to much force.
  5. Screw in the M4x30 screws, attach 2 washers and the wingnut.
  6. Attach the hinges with the M4x10 screws. Put some epoxy glue in the screw wholes before screwing in the screws.
  7. Attach the soapcutter with the wood screws to the wooden board.
  8. Install the guitar strings and align them to each other and the soap stops. Be careful with the tension of the wire, do not overtighten the strings!!
  9. Attach the soap stop with glue or screws. Test the exact position beforehand with a soap out of your mold, and do not attacht the soap stops directly in front of the forward frame (or you`ll have problems cutting hight soaps).

Have fun!

comments.text: Hey.. I'm building one... I'm using 80% infill and solid layer after 3 layers. I think it'll be strong enough without carbon fiber. But if you look online there is a soap cutter with the ends open. Do you think it'll be strong enough without one of the cross braces?
comments.author: shortcircuitaz

comments.text:
Unfortunately, no. I used the Carbon Fiber rods because i had problems of the beams bending and touching the soap stop (white parts). My wife uses a medium to high tension on the wire for clean cuts, and the Force generated by all the Wires together on the beams is impressive... on the other hand it might work without carbon if youre really careful with the tension. Depends also a lot on the filament. And if you used 80%infill (i used 20) it should work.
I really dont know what Happens without crossbeams....sorry.

author: doodady

description.text: Hello everyone! We made this fingertips mold in order to create this part in a faster way with silicone rubber. It works perfect with the fingers of the UnLimbited arm. We created two sizes for an adult person and for children of 10 years. We also add here the fusion 360 files if you want to make modifications.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

15

Steps to use it

First of all, the mold has three pieces, the two sides of the block and the finger. The finger is the last piece to put.

  1. Add a fine layer of spray silicone as unmolding tool over the two blocks and finger.
  2. Join the blocks with tape just for precaution.
  3. Prepare the mix of silicone rubber, for the quatity we calculated like the half of the blocks. Revolve very well the mix to avoid bubbles.
  4. Drop the silicone into the mold, rember fill just to the half.
  5. The final step is to put the last piece: the finger. When put it the silicone is going up to the top, and fix it with the joints to the corners.
  6. Let it dry and remove it carefully in order to not damage the mold.

Simple E3D Hotend drop in that requires no extra screws or parts!

I'll add photos later and a step by step guide.

(Temp. Guide - Feel Free to ask questions!)
In order to use this adapter you need to take the old hotend and the block it is attached to off of the cartage. Next you'll want to put the E3D hotend in between the two half blocks and then assemble it back onto the carriage. (The two half blocks and hotend go in the exact way the old hotend was installed and does not require any extra parts) As you tighten the screws the blocks will compress around the hotend and keep it very secure.

*Update*

1.Added Reinforced variant for longer lifespan and higher strength :)

This XT60 mount is designed to securely hold a female XT60 plug for use as a removable link or charging port for robotics applications. A male XT60 will nest easily ontop.

You may need to adjust the cutout to accommodate for specific printer precision. Printers with 0.2mm capabilities can make use of the perfect press-fit clearance, no glue needed.

After using 1 of these in my 30lb combat robot I discovered the male connector was susceptible to popping free after heavy shock loads. Rookie mistake, thought the friction fit was good enough when the male was plugged in. A redesign is in the works with mechanical interlocks to secure the male plug. XT60 Female Mount V2 coming soon!

I'm also working on a system for securing 4 low profile 4mm bullet connectors for a tiny printable removable link system.

title: Make #23 - Stargazy Tree Topper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Our Stargazy Tree Topper was inspired by Tom Bawcock's Eve, the festival held each year on the 23rd of December in the beautiful Cornish village of Mousehole. It commemorates the brave fisherman who saved the village from starvation just before Christmas. We love the magic of this story and the name of the pie eaten during celebrations. We just couldn'?t resist making it part of our collection! Faberdashery are releasing daily, seasonal designs for you to print and enjoy. Join in the fun with our 25 Days of Making! This is Make #23 of 25.

Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and 1% infill. At coarse resolution (0.3mm), you will find prints have extra shimmer (and print quicker!).
Created in stunning Faberdashery Galaxy Blue PLA^. The tree topper requires ~12g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~4m of 1.75mm filament) and the hanging version ~4g of material (~1m of 3mm / ~2m of 1.75mm filament). Print the Stargazy Tree Topper to finish off your tree, or the hanging version as a magical ornament.

author: lucascassiano

description.text:
This Syringe Adapter Head fits 50/60cc syringes commonly found in medical applications and can be used in air pressure dispensing applications or in paste extruders for 3d printing. It also makes a great replacements for the Makerbot Frostruder syringe adapter. With a quarter of a turn it locks and seals the syringe so you can use air pressure to dispense its contents. The adapter head consists of one part only and should be printed with support material turned on. The bolts you see in the various pictures are not used to assemble the parts but to prevent the adapter from delaminating and flying apart under pressure. The bolts are there for reinforcement.
There are other adapter heads on thingiverse but they use extra o-rings or tube connectors which are not needed in this design. Instead of an o-ring I use the rubber plunger that comes with your syringe as a seal, the tubing is friction fitted. Update June 18, 2013:
Added an extra strong version, two extra bolts to relieve stress. Thicker top and bottom + extra reinforcement beam on the top. I use this adapter with BD plastipak 50/60cc syringes, similar sized syringes from other brands will probably work too, leave your experiences in the comments and specify brand and type so I can add them to this list: Compatibility:
-BD plastipak 50/60cc

!!WARNING!!
I have operated this Syringe Adapter Head and standard medical syringes at pressures up to 6 bar for over a year without issues but I guess this is close to the limit of what it can take. Your millage may vary depending on the quality of your print and syringes and I am NOT responsible if stuff explodes and harms you, your family, your dog or anything else around you. instructions: -Print out the part SyringeAdapterHead.stl, you will need to print it with support turned on. Carefully clean the part by removing the support. There is no need to seal the part (acetone/glue...) because the syringe is sealed by the rubber plunger cap. -Drill out the 3mm holes and add 3mm bolts of sufficient length. Add washers on both sides, don't use 3mm washer but try to use larger ones that are still hold by your 3mm bolts head. -I use PL-4 tubing from FESTO that I found at bargain price, you can probably find similar stiff pneumatic tubing normally used in air pressure applications. Inside diameter is 4mm, outside is 6mm. -Check if your tubing fits the center hole, it should take some force to get it in because it should withstand the pressure by friction only. If the hole is to small, file or drill it larger but be careful not to stretch it to wide. Let the tubing stick out 5-10mm. -Take the black rubber piston from your syringe and make a tiny hole in the centre with a small drill or sharp pointy knife, now pierce the short end of the tube trough and fit the rubber on the syringe adapter, twist a bit back and forth so it fits nicely. -Test by closing a syringe (old clogged needle,...) and gradually increasing the pressure, the adapter can bend under high pressure but should hold (see picture). Wear safety glasses when testing.

author: morenot3131

description.text:
As explained by Wikipedia:

Center gauges and fishtail gauges are gauges used in lathe work for checking the angles when grinding the profiles of single-point screw-cutting tool bits and centers. In the image, the gauge on the left is called a fishtail gauge or center gauge, and the one on the right is another style of center gauge.

These gauges are most commonly used when hand-grinding threading tool bits on a bench grinder, although they may be used with tool and cutter grinders.

When the tool bit has been ground to the correct angle, they may then be used to set the tool perpendicular to the workpiece.

They can incorporate a range of sizes and types on the one gauge, the two most common being metric or UNS at 60°, and BSW at 55°. Gauges also exist for the Acme thread form.

May need another. Still have batteries laying around.

comments.author: emoretto

comments.text:
Thanks. I'm not an engineer but I'll try to answer your question.
First, accuracy: The three things that effect this would be 1) the thread per inch (TPI) on the drive shaft, 2) the degree rotation per step (1.8 I think on this stepper) and 3) the backlash on the drive nut. You can increase accuracy by 1) compensating for backlash in the arduino sketch program 2) using a zero backlash nut, or 3) having finer threads on the drive shaft and 4) by micro-stepping the stepper motor. You can achieve phenomenal sub-micro liter accuracy.
Second, error: This might be introduced by sensitivity in a limit switch or by how much you "step off" the limit switch. Stepper can also slip if the syringe plunger binds. They also don't know where they are like a servo would so you would need to prime the line before beginning.
Hope that helps.
Take a look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28179 for some Rapid Prototyping Makerbeam components.
R

comments.text:
Forgot to mention, I used shop parts not quality materials for this proof of concept prototype.
You can use an arduino with a sparkfun stepper motor controller.
To make your own Zero backlash nut ----> get two nuts, thread them onto a Vaseline coated threaded shaft, next to each other, then give them a small rotational offset. Next JB weld (epoxy) them together. There you have it, a custom zero backlash nut. You can re-mill the flat surfaces if you want but that's usually not needed since you acetone weld them in place in the ABS plastic housing.

comments.text: Hopefully these weren't directly just converted to STLs.  If they were, they're going to have some massive hollows, like behind the eyes, etc.  The originals were .obj files and I haven't found a program that will convert them to the shell version.
comments.author: thantik

comments.text: Well guess what, they are. I still lack the skills to convert them to just shells. Having said that they only have a few small cavities behind the eyes and print just fine. I had no problems at all.
currently i have a working version of Rainbow Dash without hollows. I have yet to have 4 hours to print her, but the .STL is solid. I'll post a pick when I have the print done
comments.author: dragonator

comments.text: RoboLemur, what program did you use to convert the .obj file to an STL?  Did you use any kind of plugin/filter to merge the models correctly?
comments.author: RoboLemur

comments.text: I can fix them up. (You need to "union" the parts together)
Are the legs the only parts that require support? Couldn't you, say, thicken them up to improve printability?
comments.author: cymon

comments.text: The mane, tail and the middle of the body all use support, so thickening the legs won't really improve printability. Also if you thicken parts for printing, they will be less show accurate.
comments.author: cymon

title: spool cone for filamentspool M8 nut screw Anet A8

description.text:
I've created a pair of cones to fit into my filamentspools. They can be screwed into the spool with two M8 nut-screws and a piece of threaded rod. The outer nut screews are self-locking nuts.
The biggest diameter is 61mm and the smallest 40mm. The hight of the cones is 20mm.

The cones are optimised for Kaiserlich24 spools and the overhead spoolerholder for the Anet A8.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1505075

They will fit to serveral other spools between 40mm and 60mm, too.
Also usable with the stock Anet A8 acrylic spoolholder.

created with SolidEdge ST9 EduEdition.
.par file is downloadable to modify the cone to any size.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10-15%

comments.text:

The M8 nuts which come with the Anet don't fit because they use a 14mm socket.

print_settings.Notes:: For the rake head, I used .1mm layers and slowed down to 30 mm/sec. The individual tines can be something of a challenge at this scale, and while they came out pretty good in the end I did have some stringing that I needed to (carefully!) remove between them.

description.text:
Combined a couple of existing objects on Thingiverse to create some miniature garden tools for use as decoration on a cake.

I separated the handle into its own object so it could be printed in wood PLA, and the fit should be tight enough on the tab that either the rake or shovel head should stay on without glue (though it doesn't hurt to put a drop or two on).

The void in the tool head is only .2mm larger then the tab on the handle, so if your machine's tolerances are a bit off you may need to file it down a bit to make sure it snaps together.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 - 0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The handle and shovel head are pretty simple, and don't really need any special consideration. Layer height of .2mm is fine, and as fast as you want.

For the rake head, I used .1mm layers and slowed down to 30 mm/sec. The individual tines can be something of a challenge at this scale, and while they came out pretty good in the end I did have some stringing that I needed to (carefully!) remove between them.

author: good_idea

description.text: neopost ds-75

Read Across America day is celebrated in many schools on March 2, the birthday of popular children's writer Dr. Seuss. The goal is to promote reading with fun activities.

http://www.seussville.com/Educators/educatorReadAcrossAmerica.php

In this project middle school students will create a customized bookmark.
NGSS

The objective is for each student to make a bookmark they can use.  The students have enough experience with Tinkercad and 3D design that they don't require any instruction on how to make them. They were shown examples, and given a plain model they could modify if they wished.

Students were given some general guidelines for their designs
  • Part that goes inside book should be 1 mm thick, and flat or nearly flat
  • Part that goes outside book can be thicker but must have a flat bottom for printing
  • Good idea to have a long flat side that will lay along the spine of the book
    • Designs on the part that goes inside the book were made as 0.5 mm engravings so the piece remained flat.
Some sample bookmarks can be helpful. Obviously you need a 3D printer and filament, and access to 3D design software such as Tinkercad.

author: solodo

description.text:
This is a cutlery Adapter that allow eating and cut food to people with hand movement problems (this was designed for a patient that has lost his thumb)

Makes easier hold cutlery by thickening the handle and surronding the hand.

The internal channel can be changed in order to hold diferent things like a thicker cutlery, a tooth brush, a pencil, etc.

This object was made for the "Mutual de Seguridad C.Ch.C" from Chile. In a project of the Direction of innovation and development, and the Neuro rehabilitation institute.

How to ensamble it
  1. You need a heat gun, cutlery and the printed adapter. 2. Heat the part of the adapter indicated in the figure, put it on the patient hand and shape it (be carreful because if it's too hot it can burn the patient). 3. Insert the cutlery in the cannel and heat the start of it, smash it with a pliers.

author: jogurcig

title: Filament Holder Redux with junction box

description.text:
Hello. This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1743397 done by dldesign. I have not changed the functionality of his design, I have however added a "junction box" on the right support intended to house a power switch and a second box on the left support designed to hold up to three accessory switches-- lid designs for the left box have been included with both 2 and 3 mounting holes on the lid.

The spool holder braces replace the spacers for the LCD board and can be used with or without the center filament guide. Guide cup is large enough to include a sponge if so desired.

Supports: Everywhere

I made this box for the ardiuno nano board and the sensor for the DIY Head Tracker on RcGroups. The box has no mechanical fasteners just a tight fit. If it doesn't hold well use a little hot glue on the inside corners and then push it together. I may update the design, when I get some time, and add four small screws in the corners.   
I updated the box and added screws to the corners. The screws are 3X12mm countersunk self tapping. There pretty common and should be at all the hobby shops. I also mad the usb hole a little bigger, it was a bit to tight.  
I made a couple more changes on this box and labeled it V4. I changed to some small 2mm wood screws for a cleaner look and i made the inside of the box a little deeper to accommodate the pins on the ardiuno board. You will still need to remove the 6 pins on the end.

author: janemiceli

title: Yet Another Ikea Lack Enclosure (Wanhao Duplicator Plus)

description.text:
Looking for an enclosure for a Wanhao Duplicator Plus, I came across many different designs utilizing the Ikea Lack table. My primary inspiration comes from Kirby Downey's design (https://www.myminifactory.com/object/ikea-lack-table-enclosure-adapter-26769), but there were several things his design lacked that I wanted in mine. His designs are beautiful but a bit difficult to edit, so I created mine from scratch. I disliked the asymmetrical design that put all the height in the feet, and figured that if I altered it to have matching pieces at the top and bottoms of the legs that it would give me a natural way to hold plexiglass sides.

Here are the goals I have with my design:

  • symmetric design
  • built-in wall holders
  • mount on top of existing computer desk
  • integrated hinges, door stops, mounting points

I created a few different designs and modified as I went. Thanks to many great designs I didn't have to start from scratch, specifically I have used or incorporated the following objects:

  • Lack Filament Grommet (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1821844)
  • Quick Hinge (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:47591)
  • Door Handle (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36465)

For the most part everything worked the first time. I will be uploading v2 designs that fix a few of the issues I ran into in assembly. The two basic changes are: 1) add mounting points to the inside of the corner bracket to securely attach to the table top and base; 2) add stops to the hinge bottoms to hold the door in place without screws.

The pin on my quick hinges proved too brittle and broke off of each hinge. I took a drill bit and drilled out the broken part and cleaned up the hole on the other part, then screwed a simple machine screw in each and it works perfectly.

Additional Materials:

  • 36 in. x 48 in. x .093 in. Acrylic Sheet - makes 3 windows and 1 door
  • 12V Flexible RGB LED Light Strip Kit
  • SDHC SD Card Reader Extension Cable KZ-B19

edited 2/28/2017

  • fixed mis-named parts
  • fixed bad shelve design in previous version
  • added screw holes on shelves

edited 3/1/2017

  • uploaded updated hinges
  • added pics of LED light strips using 3d printed bracket (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2111131)
  • removed front mounted z-braces and replaced with Reverse Z Braces (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2144122)

comments.text: I printed everything. and is it just me or the hinges are reversed? if I put the hinges on the corners, the solid part is on top (bottom hinge). so you cant really put the acrylic sheet. I tried a lot of combination and flipping of the 2 hinges that I printed but nothing works.
comments.author: kamoteshake

comments.text: My apologies, you're correct. I corrected the two hinges (rev3) and the overall doc (rev3b) and have uploaded them.

comments.author: kamoteshake

comments.text: I picked up one of the orange boxes of screws while at Ikea getting the Lack. I don't have specifics but used 16 screws attaching the corner pieces to the top. 4 corners, 2 screws per side.  Then two screws for the hinges.
comments.author: kamoteshake

comments.text: awesome!. thanks!.
comments.author: Mframe

comments.text: I printed these at 100% and couldn't get a single leg to fit. I reprinted at 103% and they fit, but now 6 of the 8 corners are simply incorrect. The back top left and right are correct. The other six all have their "shelves" in the middle of the piece, hanging out into space, instead of even with the end of a leg after it is inserted into the socket. This would allow the shelf to be flush with the top or bottom of the table. Also, two of the STLs have their names switched.
comments.author: clairm

comments.text: Sorry you had problems with it, but I'm not quite sure what to tell you about sizing without more details of your print.  I printed at 100% using Hatchbox PLA, no heat on the bed, with a 30% infill.  There was no shrinkage or warping to speak of. The fit is tight, intentionally so, and I had to work the edges of the legs in.  The pieces do flex just enough to go around the legs, though it will start to peel the very edges of the laminate on the legs.  Any scuffing is ultimately hidden by the design.
comments.author: clairm

comments.text: Just looking at the images, these look much better. With almost 200 hours into printing these things twice, I'm reluctant to print them one more time. Maybe I'll replace the pieces one at a time over time. One other thing, I had no trouble with the hinge pins breaking off, but the holes for the pins were too small. I pulled the two small hinge pieces into Sketchup and enlarged the holes and they worked fine. It looks like you removed the grooves for the acrylic from those pieces, is that correct?
comments.author: Mframe

comments.text: Yes, I would definitely print one test piece first (probably one of the rear corners) before investing in printing them all.  Print it and make sure it fits your leg.
comments.author: clairm

comments.text: My first attempt (too small to fit the legs) was white MonoPrice PLA, at the default Cura PLA settings, except 0.2mm layers and 20% fill. With those the hinge pins broke easily, so maybe my temperature needs to be adjusted for that filament.
comments.author: Mframe

comments.text: Great, let us know how it turns out!
comments.author: clairm
